awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, new computational methods are applied to the texts of more than 3,000 local revenue measures that were subject to voter referendums in more and less diverse places.  These data are used to investigate how tax policy characteristics may moderate the known effects of diversity on voters' willingness to pay for public spending.  The results will yield new insights into what makes for a sustainable revenue source.  This is crucial for enabling American society to meet the fiscal challenges of the future, and thus for the health, prosperity and welfare of American society as well as for national security. 

The project involves the assembly and digitization of revenue measures presented to local voters since 1986. Supervised and unsupervised machine learning techniques then are applied to classify these measures and to identify features of the text that mediate the observed associations between diversity and reported election outcomes. The most general goal of the project is to identify institutional mechanisms that moderate associations between social context and public spending. A more specific goal is to identify the causes of the well-known negative association between diversity and public spending on health, welfare, and other social transfers and services. The project thereby advances theoretical understanding of the dimensions of policy that affect voting behavior. It also analyzes institutional mechanisms that yield one of the most important observed patterns in fiscal sociology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The achievement of fiscal sustainability is important for the health, prosperity and welfare of American society. This study was designed to improve our understanding of how to achieve fiscal sustainability by analyzing how public policy design affects the willingness of voters to pay for public goods in our diverse democracy. The study focused on California, because of its size, its diversity of local governments and economies, and its unique constitutional requirements that allow voters to consider, and vote on, most proposals to fund local government. Although California is not typical of other U.S. states, much less of the rest of the world, it is so big and so varied that many other states are similar in at least some relevant respects to one or another part of California. The findings of this project therefore may be relevant to social scientists who are trying to understand the challenges of achieving fiscal sustainability in other states of the U.S. and even some other economically developed, democratic countries.

To discover how policy design affects voting behavior, the researchers collected, digitized, and archived more than 3,000 policy documents that were presented to voters in local elections in California since 1986. These documents are now available for download from a public library archive and can be used in civic education and for further research. 

To draw conclusions from this archive, the researchers also processed a subset of these documents for statistical analysis of their semantic contents. Processing some of these documents into a machine-readable form allowed researchers to use a computer algorithm to classify policies into five different types just as accurately, and much faster, than a human reader could. It also allowed the researchers to design a computational model that could do something human readers could not do on their own, namely, to measure degrees of similarity and difference between the text of any given policy and the texts of the other policies that voters were most likely to support.

The research found that policies to pay for local public goods in California municipalities were most popular to the degree that their text seemed to describe risk pooling. This term designates a policy that raises funds from a category of people who are at common risk for a particular kind of misfortune, and then allocates those funds to mitigate the misfortune for everyone in the category who experiences it. One example of a policy that involves risk pooling is a tax on all town residents to pay for local ambulance service, so that the ambulance service is there for those town residents who happen to need it. The researchers found that policies are also more popular to the degree that they are more community-oriented, meaning that they distinguish between local residents and nonresidents. By measuring these two features of a policy, it is possible to predict what percentage of voters will support it; such predictions are not as accurate as public opinion polls, but they are, on average, about as accurate as predictions from statistical models that are based on information about characteristics of the electorate.

The project also aimed to identify whether these policy design features affect how much voters’ willingness to pay for public goods differed between more and less racially and ethnically diverse places. Using a population of ballot measures proposed and adopted in California school districts from 1996 to 2010, it was possible to measure the association between racial diversity and school finance outcomes. In these elections, racial composition made a difference to whether or not school district officials were likely to place a school finance measure on the ballot. School boards were least likely to propose new school finance measures when the racial and ethnic composition of the older voting-age residents of the district was most different from the racial and ethnic composition of the student body enrolled in public schools. Once a measure was on the ballot, however, the racial composition of the student body did not affect the average likelihood that voters would support it, and policy design features did not make any difference to this pattern of outcomes.
